You can have Lake Wobegon if there‚Äôs as many ways to excel as people. Everybody gets humaning participation trophy for being best at something. The problem with this is a) there‚Äôs no grounding in survival/adaptation truth signal b) it‚Äôs not actually a fun human condition

In case it isn‚Äôt obvious, everybody best at something = everybody worst at the same thing = no variation for natural selection = cultural evolution at a degenerate stall condition. In practice it means evolution proceeds via illegible selection pressures under overwrought order

In fact even when there is enough dimensional room for all, people will congregate in a few. Humans *want* community enough they‚Äôd rather be average in the competitive company of at least a subculture than ‚Äúexcellent‚Äù by default as the sole person doing something.

Where‚Äôs there is collective experience there are comparisons, variations, selections... and cream/middle/dregs parts of the distribution. This is a good thing. Don‚Äôt try to stack-rank humanity by skimming off the cream and destroying the rest.

The existence of mediocrity is a consequence of humans valuing sociability enough to give up some exceptionalism for it. I write in part because writing is work where I can have company, even if it means being mostly mediocre at it and dealing with resulting social consequences.

We‚Äôre also smarter as a collective species than as individuals. Yes there‚Äôs a tax of bureaucracy/‚Äúinnovation by committee‚Äù but hive minds of grain-fed runts still out-evolved scattered beef-only nomad barbarians. Only takes a small dose of exceptionalism and it‚Äôs Advantage Borg.

So for a) social psychological reasons b) efficiencies of scale/concentration c) higher collective intelligence. The human condition is always lower dimensional than what technology allows, and is a function of population, not possibility.

Mediocrity is safety net of psyche. You sustain it by creating modes of being that *large numbers of people can participate in at acceptable levels in Borg/Death Star mode*. This is in fact what the ‚Äúdemocratization‚Äù of platform capitalism is. Clouds of average human computers.

Democratization is mediocratization. The reduction in the number of special traits (genetic, educational, virtues, class) required to participate in a function. The fundamental contradiction inherent in hustle porn and celebration of excellence is ignoring this powerful force.

With apologies to A. N. Whitehead, civilization advances by extending the number of operations humans can perform without being exceptional or OCD.

You want to level up the world? Replace a genius function, not with an AI, but with something a half-engaged slacker can phone in.

Seattle is squeezing mediocrity hard right now. And predictably there‚Äôs more, and crazier, homeless people on the streets, whose mental health/drug use is a bigger issue than their poverty. Almost as bad as San Francisco now. This is what happens when you wage war on mediocrity.

Be careful what you wish for in wishing mediocrity would go away. You‚Äôre saying: make it to the top or break down and fall to the human garbage pile. Mediocrity is  sustainable ‚Äúfake it a bit till you die happy‚Äù option. Not ‚Äúfake it till you make it or fail and die of insanity.‚Äù

Mediocritism isn‚Äôt socialism by the way. Capitalism is a 10x better engine of mediocratization than any kind of socialism *if* you don‚Äôt fetishize it. I suspect vaguely socialist modes of societal organization emerge as an overcompensation when mediocrity is stressed too hard.

This happens when exceptionalists and excellentists drink their own ‚Äúmeritocracy‚Äù kool-aid too much and start believing in master races, superhumans and other statistically dubious eugenics fever dream misreadings of how capitalism actually works.

Ironically you know what‚Äôs a sure sign of mass exceptionalist thinking? Overly muscular systems of ‚Äúmeritocracy‚Äù thinking. You know where they believe super strongly in that? China. It‚Äôs the party line that all Chinese are above average if you standardize testing enough.

Capitalism works not by raising floor or ceiling but by dragging up middle via democratization-mediocratization. Misreading this is basically a case  of  being so terrified of being merely ordinary, and people who accept a contemporary ordinary life, you wage war on mediocrity.

So dare to be ordinary, huddle in the middle, slack off, say fuck-off to excellence/meritocracy/hustle religions and Make Meh Great Again üôÇ

---

## 25. Killing People to Reboot Things

*January 24, 2019*

It‚Äôs when you consider problems like air traffic control (ATC) on a busy continent that practical problems with libertarianism become apparent. It‚Äôs a tightly synchronized federated architecture (ie a network of locally centralized entities) that‚Äôs hard to ‚Äúlibertarianize‚Äù

There have been technical proposals over last 20 years for distributed ATC protocols (planes coordinating directly with each other) requiring low or zero ground control elements. After all birds fly around without ATCs. The problem is transitioning to such systems.

The existing solution is decades old, with a lot of metis (tacit knowledge) accumulated over the years. Switching away from it is 1000x harder than switching away from the QWERTY keyboard. It‚Äôs about as hard as switching regular money to crypto. Doable in principle, cost unclear.

Recipe: take some snazzy cutting-edge decentralized ATC ideas (for eg like https://news.engin.umich.edu/2018/11/decentralized-air-traffic-control-for-drone-laden-skies/), throw in AlphaGo to mine all the metis from historical records, re-solve it better starting from blank slate like AlphaGoZero, download to all your planes/drones, fire all ATCs.

You can imagine the end state: no ATCs at all. Planes and airlines do it all in decentralized software, government gets out of the act, tickets cost a bit more to pay for it all, taxes go down more, everybody wins. The Lords Koch are happy, 1 step closer to night-watchman state.

Wouldn‚Äôt it be lovely if we could have software, decentralization, and blockchain eat ALL government functions this way? Nothing for governments to do, nothing to be shut down. Ayn Rand smiles down from her place in insane heaven.

The problem with this scenario is that the transition cost might well be ‚Äúcollapse of civilization.‚Äù Transitioning a function like ATC to decentralized utopian future might be, to coin a phrase, ‚Äúcollapse complete.‚Äù You might have to blow it ALL up to achieve ONE such transition.

That‚Äôs the problem with a lot of libertarian visions. They are quite possibly collapse complete. Achieving any one of them might require ‚Äúcollapse‚Äù as a transient state. ATC is just one of dozens of critical ‚Äústack  realities‚Äù (public health, disaster relief, food security...)

But there may be non-collapse clever pathways to achieve such transitions. We‚Äôre navigating one (energy) right now. The small problem is some are impatient and want to try blowing up what we have to redo the whole thing, taking a leap of faith that it‚Äôs NOT collapse complete.

The BIG problem is that many believe such transitions ARE in fact unavoidably collapse complete and *still* want them. Effectively they want to bunker down with civilizational crown jewels/reboot plans, let us other 99% subhumans die off, and emerge from bat caves to rule in 2119

These are awful people, but they do exist, do hold such views and serious power, and do in fact react with glee to progress in BTFSTTG (burn the fucking shit to the ground) plans. 200 years ago BTFSTTG was a silly dream. In 2019, it could actually be done (reboot not guaranteed)

These are  ‚ÄúSometimes Going Galt needs a Donald Trump to clear the way‚Äù people. Aka Claremont conservatives operating with a ‚ÄúFlight 93‚Äù theology. A sort of ‚Äúwe must burn it all down to save it‚Äù mindset. https://www.claremont.org/crb/basicpage/the-flight-93-election/

Now we technological pragmatists still want to get to nice decentralized future outcomes, but we want to muddle through, in a messy, constant ‚Äúunder construction‚Äù slouching-towards-utopia way. We don‚Äôt want to blow it all up. We don‚Äôt want to BTFSTTG along the way.

This is why the shutdown concern me. This isn‚Äôt like previous shutdowns. This is a shutdown with a lot of BTFSTTG types in power. Their BATNA (best alternative to a negotiated agreement) is collapse. Maybe not ATC, but they‚Äôd like to see a lot of stack realities collapse for good

Sure the risk of a crash caused by a fatigued unpaid controller moonlighting driving Lyft, leading to a strike, is low. But I bet there‚Äôs BTFSTTG people thinking ‚Äúwe could use a gory crash to force privatization of ATC, on the road to automation and eventual elimination. Win!‚Äù

Government shrinkage by starvation collapse ‚Äî> privatize ‚Äî> automate. Gut what you can, when you can to transition it to your utopian state via crash chaos.  There‚Äôs  people in power who actually want lots of things to break and not be fixed. Reaganomics but with violent sadism.

This is why, though I actually share many libertarian and ancap end goals, I don‚Äôt identify as either. I think most of them fetishize technology in illiterate sci-fi ways, understand it in micro bits that makes them overconfident about macro things, and are basically sadists.

Starting a slide towards a Hobbesian world because they think they can come out the other end as winners. Because they‚Äôre idiots who think because they‚Äôre rich, they must be smart. Because they like apocalypse movies, they must be like The Rock themselves.

Am I overstating things? Well, here we are, talking about diverting actual disaster relief funds to build a symbolic wall and wondering if it will take an airplane crash to get governance back, by people who will then predictably exploit the tragedy to burn more things down.

This is what lunatics running the asylum looks like. Not ‚Äúmove fast and break things‚Äù which could at least be justified as calibrated risk-taking.

No, this is ‚Äúdeliberately break things and hurt/kill people to reboot things‚Äù sadistic playbook.

Happy Day 34 of a shutdown world.

---

## 26. Snobby Holmesean Cases with Singular Features

*January 29, 2019*

I'm becoming more snobby about work than I can probably afford to be from a financial perspective. Like Sherlock Holmes, I require "singular features" to take a case. I can spot the consulting equivalent of a "evidence of cheating spouse for a divorce case" a mile off now.

A big truth of work-adulting is that 90% of business problems are at best mildly stimulating and tricky the first 3 times, and then boring and straightforward for n>3. You just have to grind through them. They require neither book smarts nor street smarts. Just sweat and time.

The only ways to make them ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù is to 

a) add more money
b) add more unmodelable risk
c) add an interpersonal caring dimension for someone you like/love or dislike/hate
d) add a self-care dimension (proving yourself after self-esteem blow, healing narcissistic wound)

If $ and risk don‚Äôt motivate you, you have to either find the remaining 10% of problems or go into other fields. I‚Äôd say 90% of the 10% interesting business problems (ie 9% of total) are at VP+ levels, but the 1% lurking lower down food chain are the very best problems.

Unless you find this 10%, almost any other field has a higher proportion of ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù

Engineering/Art: 30-80% interesting 
Housework: 20-40% interesting

Even the *boring* parts are more interesting. Routine tech calculations, ‚Äúlaying pipe‚Äù in novel writing, folding laundry

Typical ‚Äú90% boring part‚Äù problems: dealing with problem coworker/boss/report, navigating a tedious political conflict involving people you don‚Äôt give a shit about, interpreting sales data, reading balance sheets, rerunning a spreadsheet model for the 4th year in a row.

People are generally paid in proportion to how much boredom they take on. And the boredom is a mark of competence by the way. Anyone who loves these problems past n=3 is likely cluelessly awful at dealing with them. Their incompetence lends interestingness to routine stuff.

In 2019, with everybody either exhorting you to ‚Äúlearn to code‚Äù or ‚Äúbecome an entrepreneur‚Äù it is good to know why neither might fit you. Coding is easy to eliminate. You find out fairly quickly the hard way (6-12 months) whether you have a feel for it and are good at it.

Entrepreneurship is harder. The primary qualification is the courage to be bored for long periods of time without getting distracted. At least 5 years. Like, 90% of the time until an org of people to do the boring bits exists under your authoritah. I lack this.

If you‚Äôre not bored by the 90% you lack the imagination to solve the 10%. If you don‚Äôt have the courage you won‚Äôt endure 5 years of boredom. Life FOMO will claim you (‚Äúthere‚Äôs got to be more to life than playing half a dozen games that seem to involve gearing ‚Äòno‚Äô repeatedly!‚Äù)

And if you eliminate both coding and entrepreneurship what‚Äôs left?

Everything else.

---

## 27. Blue Collar Innovation

*February 2, 2019*

A thread on innovation theory pointing out some connections that have been clear in my head for years, but I‚Äôm realizing are not even visible to many people interested in the topic. I‚Äôm always surprised when I have to point these things out and pass along these references.

In the history of innovation revolutions, after the pioneer stage but before the institutional phase, you usually have a ‚Äúblue-collar innovator mutual-influence network‚Äù, BCIMIN, basically consisting of people dropping in on each other‚Äôs workspaces and freely stealing tricks.

Here I overload ‚Äúblue-collar innovator‚Äù to mean anyone producing stuff using an emerging medium of any sort, not just physical making. So early bloggers or first cohort of bands in a new music scene count.  Sorry if that offends your class sensibilities but it‚Äôs the best term.

Out of necessity they have to work on/around deficiencies of medium and get hands dirty. Typically they are much more deeply knowledgeable about their tools than later institutional era non-innovator blue-collar types, who will also work at the tool level, but at stable maturity.

Often they may seem ‚Äúoverqualified‚Äù for the tool level. Early computing pioneers like Turing, von Neumann, and Richard Hamming were often mathematicians who knew vastly more math than modern programmers ever learn. If formally credentialed, they may look like they‚Äôre slumming it.

Interesting datapoint: much of the hands-on early work on drones and driverless cars was done at university labs by people getting Masters or PhD degrees. They did everything from soldering to writing advanced math papers. But today a high-school kid can work with the tech.

But credentials are not necessary for a BCIMIN. Only the impedance mismatch between the depth of knowledge and experience being brought to bear on the work, and the seemingly ‚Äúbeneath them‚Äù level of hands-on-work and mucking about at the tool level.

I‚Äôve seen credentialed, decorated types literally turn up their noses with ‚Äúthis is contractor/intern/newbie grunt work‚Äù. When a respected, high-reputation person says something like that, I immediately flip the bozobit and look skeptically at their supposed great reputation.

Invariably I find they‚Äôve been doing shallow, dull work aimed at racking up institutional merit points (number of papers/patents, awards etc). They are the Paris Hiltons of innovation. Famous for being famous. A resume stuffed with everything except blue-collar innovation.

Blue-collar innovators are ‚Äúnew medium pilot plant‚Äù producers. Their workspaces/tooling are inbetween basic research labs and scaled production. They produce in small batches not because they have artisan sensibilities but because they‚Äôre pushing the scaling limits of new media.

BCIMINs are the most stimulating and energizing place for most smart, creative, imaginative, and growth-oriented people to participate in. It‚Äôs not the rare lightning-strike regime that creates pioneers, nor is it the predictable world of institutions built around stable tools.

I‚Äôd guess 1% of the population will end up as pioneers, 9% as blue-collar innovators, and 90% as mature-institution normies. Of that 90%, a third to half (so 30-45% of total) will be bullshit workers, predators and parasites at maturity. Free riders of one sort or the other.

This is fine. I approve of non-producing free riders right up to the point that kills the host process of wealth creation. It‚Äôs only good wealth if it produces a surplus, and somebody has to consume it. Somebody has to eat all that cake.

Modern startup ecosystems and open-source communities before large-scale financialization are of course the most familiar example of BCIMINs, but it‚Äôs a more general phenomenon. See for example steam engines after James Watt‚Äôs patents expired: https://www.jstor.org/stable/23603566?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents

Robert Allen called BCIMINs ‚Äúcollective invention settings‚Äù (his concept is the basis for the paper above). A more contemporary model is settler phase of Cringley‚Äôs pioneer-settler-town planner model which @swardley incorporated into his mapping model. https://blog.gardeviance.org/2015/03/on-pioneers-settlers-town-planners-and.html

The model applies to cultural production too. See the idea of scene-hacking from @sebpaquet https://www.slideshare.net/mobile/vgururao/scene-hacking

And to general intellectual production. See Fred Turner on ‚Äúnetwork celebrity‚Äù https://fredturner.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/Turner-Larson-Network-Celebrity-PC-2015.pdf

See also @Meaningness on the underlying social evolution process. https://meaningness.com/geeks-mops-sociopaths

BCIMINs are a *natural* expression of human motivations. When they are repressed, potential blue-collar innovators turn to crime and other pathological activities. You can‚Äôt get rid of the 9%. See this Baumol paper. https://www.jstor.org/stable/2937617?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents

For fun fictional portraits of a BCIMIN era, try Terry Pratchett‚Äôs Raising Steam or HBO‚Äôs Deadwood. 

Let‚Äôs finish with some subtle takeaways.

1. Innovation watchers often uncritically fetishize either credentialed expertise or unqualified blue-collar doerism. Nope. BCIMINs run on expertise (credentialed or not) *slumming at blue-collar levels*. Get this wrong and you‚Äôll end up either academic posturing or JohnHenryism.

2. The 90% normies often assume the 1% pioneers are the only ones who matter and form ‚Äúscenes‚Äù of personality cults around them. The 9% BCIMIN types are often viewed with suspicion and become targets of societal policing. This never works. They just turn to crime etc.

3. Unlike the 1%, who have a love-hate tortured relationship with fame and the attention of the 90%, the 9% neither attract, nor crave the spotlight. But they will not toe the lines or conform to societal norms or social proof either. They‚Äôll tolerate some spotlight as a burden.

4. They aren‚Äôt a community. They are a network of competing/cooperating individuals stealing tricks from each other. Ideas diffuse slowly through the BCIMIN, as each skeptically tests tricks before adopting. It‚Äôs not viral meme floods. It‚Äôs a slow network with fad defenses.

All this is fairly well-known and uncontroversial to students of innovation history. But people who enter BCIMINs attracted by 1% personality cults or with an uncritical fetish for either credentials or blue-collarism invariably don‚Äôt last. They crash and burn as scenesters.

---

## 28. Fractals, Foxes, and Hedgehogs

*February 17, 2019*

‚ÄúThe fox knows many things, the hedgehog knows one big thing‚Äù ‚Äî Isaiah Berlin

A question: how do foxes and hedgehogs ‚Äúknow‚Äù fractal realities, self-similar across scales? How do they act on them?

Answer: badly but in different ways.

Cauliflowers collapse cognition: a thread

Fractals are the enemy of tractable ontology. They suck hedgehog attention down to lowest level/highest resolution phenomenology, destroying efficient abstraction hierarchies, and cause foxes to degenerate into vertigo-inducing scale-free apophenia. Why?

The only ‚Äúefficient‚Äù kind of scale-free thinking is recursive thinking, and human brains are bad at it. Maybe we have limited stack capacity. This is why puzzles like the ‚Äúblue forehead‚Äù are hard. The logic isn‚Äôt hard, but it involves recursion. https://curiosity.com/topics/the-blue-forehead-brain-teaser-curiosity/

Imagine approximating a cauliflower with a solid that follows contours of largest florets using a parametrized mushroom-shaped primitive. That would cause both positive/negative errors (solid where empty, empty where solid). That‚Äôs a good example of a fractal map-territory error.

To get more accuracy you would use a smaller ‚Äúmushroom‚Äù as your 3D tesselation primitive. All the way down to the smallest where you‚Äôd get ‚Äúriced‚Äù cauliflower (down to rice-sized pieces). The basic idea of fractal models is to use geometrically similar primitives at all scales.

The ‚Äúcoastline of Norway‚Äù is a more conventional example but I prefer cauliflowers since they are things we act on, by chopping etc. The ‚Äúright way‚Äù to chop a cauliflower, as my buddy @bumblebeelabs once observed, is ‚Äúrecursively‚Äù.

Recursive chopping is when you decide on a target floret size (say 1/2‚Äù) and break down big florets to roughly that size. It will never be perfect. But you can get most of the mass under a hard upper limit of size in the form of florets with integrity. There Will Be Crumbles.

Most good cauliflower recipes call for a floret-integrity-preserving deconstruction (I detest things like mashed cauliflower which destroy its character ü§¨). But it‚Äôs possible to take a simpler chopping approach. Like the dicing of potato.

Chopping cauliflower with a potato technique leads to a lot of waste for a target size. Imagine ‚Äúdicing‚Äù cauliflower into half-inch cubes using knife strokes that follow a cuboidal grid. You‚Äôd get unpredictable fragments. But the smaller your target size, the less it matters.

At the limit, to get to ‚Äúriced‚Äù cauliflower, the technique kinda doesn‚Äôt matter: recursive chopping, dicing, and grating, all lead to roughly the same results: a cauliflower-insulting state good only for mushy potato or rice substitution. Structural destruction is path agnostic.

That‚Äôs what pure hedgehogs do: getting very detail-oriented by reducing the cauliflower to limit where fractal geometry gives way to the next lower level of organization (cellular).  They destroy what they can‚Äôt grok, to reduce to a perfect ‚Äúone big thing‚Äù lower-level idea.

Pure foxes otoh get attached to maintaining the integrity of the loose ‚Äúfloret‚Äù primitive to the point where they can‚Äôt recursively chop at all, since every cut, whether fractal or dicing, causes ‚Äúnon-floret-like error‚Äù to accumulate. There Will Be Crumbles. And stemmy bits.

Because there‚Äôs no ‚Äúflat‚Äù (1 level/size band) approximate breakdown with no ‚Äúerrors‚Äù (ie only floret shapes and within a size band with non-trivial upper and lower limits), the fox is tempted to deep fry the whole, holistic cauliflower so to speak. Or more likely, do nothing.

(More technically, every reduction to a size band between 0 (riced) and 1 (whole cauliflower) either introduces new ‚Äúfake‚Äù primitives like weird ‚Äústem junction cubes‚Äù that are artifacts of decomposition technique, or violates a lower size bound).

Because the fox ‚Äúknows many things‚Äù (the florets in their analogical variety, across sizes and parametric shape variations), *any* chopping is too destructive and they freeze into inaction. This is one failure mode induced by fractal realities.

Because the hedgehog  ‚Äúknows one big thing‚Äù that won‚Äôt tolerate fractal variety, they destroy the whole thing and tame it with brute force. This is another failure mode induced by fractal realities.

Both are driven by fear of incompleteness of existing knowledge.

In both cases the solution is to accept that *any* action will change reality in a way that makes your previous knowledge incomplete. So you either have to destroy the reality entirely or accept that creative destructive action creates bits that don‚Äôt fit what you know.

Basically the only error-free map is the entire territory. Hedgehogs forcefully tame it into ‚Äúrice‚Äù, foxes leave it untouched, representing the ‚Äúfloret gestalt‚Äù. Destroy the territory through reductionism, or treat it like a holistic map with no agency for you.

Non-fractal realities don‚Äôt have this property. For example, animals are not fractal. So a simpler level-by-level deconstruction works. This is Lao Tze‚Äôs butcher, taking reality apart at joints elegantly. Disassembly without fractal chopping. Our normal thinking is like this.

Under normal conditions, we tend to use ‚Äústack‚Äù thinking: a set of single-level, mutually exclusive, collectively exhaustive (MECE) mental models. We ignore fractal error. We move abstraction levels as necessary, trusting state to stay well-behaved.

Stack structures can be navigated with lightweight stacks in the computing sense. This is because they follow a finite ontogeny recipe. 

But large-scale *growing* realities tend to be fractal in macro structure. When you try to navigate them with stack logic, things fall apart.

The @EpsilonTheory essay ‚ÄúAs Above, So Below‚Äù in the ‚Äúthings fall apart‚Äù series gets at this. https://www.epsilontheory.com/things-fall-apart-part-3-politics/

My gloss on that is: under normal conditions stack thinking in a fractal world causes fractal map-territory errors that self-correct via foxes and hedgehogs serving as checks and balances on each other. That‚Äôs complex systems homeostasis.

But in weird conditions, they compound fractally, collapsing at all levels. The widening-gyre effect. Hedgehogs become part of problem by getting destructive. Foxes give up in frozen inaction. The system gets ungovernable. Self-correction homeostasis breaks down, all unravels.

The solution is to ‚Äúthink entangled, act spooky‚Äù as I recently argued. To arrest and reverse a fractal collapse you have to think in fractal-native scale-free ways. How do you do that in practice? I don‚Äôt know yet. Working on it. https://www.ribbonfarm.com/2018/09/11/think-entangled-act-spooky/

---

## 29. Risk vs. Depth

*March 3, 2019*

Realizing I‚Äôve never actually learned anything non-tactile/physical (like swimming or bike-riding) as a result of explicitly trying to learn it. It‚Äôs always been a side effect of something else (like reading for pleasure) or wanting to do or make something.

All my explicit ‚Äústudy‚Äù habits suck. I don‚Äôt take notes, I rarely go ‚Äúback to basics‚Äù to read foundational ‚Äúclassics‚Äù, I don‚Äôt do practice exercises unless they are like puzzles for fun (a criterion is satisfied by most math-based skills fortunately). I don‚Äôt learn ‚Äúgood form‚Äù

I do have what you might call ‚Äúwild cousin‚Äù behaviors to disciplined learning. I repeat good stories I‚Äôve heard. I put a lot of direct quotes and oblique references in my writing. I tend to think about everyday contemporary topics where relevant information is socially cached.

At a macro level, everything I do is unapologetically, even gleefully derivative in some sense. Any value comes from the risk rather than skill or imagination. Eg: using The Office to interpret management theory, without being skilled at either screenwriting or textbook MBA stuff

This is not ‚Äúmaking connections across fields‚Äù (which requires some depth in to/from fields. Nor is it playing ‚Äúchess postman‚Äù which requires some careful systematic left-brained bridge building. It‚Äôs more like shallow right-brained arbitrage.

This is a very lean, differential-diagnosis focused survivalist thinking style that basically surfs the learning already in the environment and/or embeddable in natural work output. A mediocre-small-brain style. It has strengths (speed being big one) but also serious blind spots.

First, it doesn‚Äôt work on topics that aren‚Äôt simultaneously being worked by lots of other people. Preferably focused types who are likely to miss obvious things that are in peripheral vision or first-order ‚Äúirrelevant‚Äù. So you can‚Äôt do far out stuff being worked by like 5 people.

Second, it doesn‚Äôt work on things that require skill stacks deeper than 2. An example is building hardware/software integrated things, which is at least about 3 layers deep (physical design, physical fabrication, software). This is an interesting one...worth a <sidebar>

I don‚Äôt think I ever made/hacked/repaired anything non-trivial more than 1 layer deep. For eg, I‚Äôve built decently complex model gliders, rigged up electronics layer for stuff with existing hardware/software things, and fixed 1-factor issues (eg pure electrical or pure plumbing)

...but I‚Äôve never made or hacked anything requiring 2 stack layers. Eg full model plane with remote controls. Closest I came was a kit robot but I never got past a few hello-world programs that made it go around in circles. I quit when I couldn‚Äôt fix a simple coupled problem...

If you‚Äôre curious, I couldn‚Äôt get wheel alignment perfect. So an open-loop straight line program would cause a slow turn. I‚Äôd have had to either true the steering, compensate in software or design and add a position feedback sensor loop... lost patience, gave up.

Same story in software. Software has both stack levels (source, compiled, environment...) and lifecycle stages (dev/production). I‚Äôve built complex single-level/single-stage things (Matlab basically) but go to 2, and I‚Äôve never gotten beyond hello-world level complexity.

Implication: I only hold 1 context in head at a time and largely surf natural dynamics in that context intuitively, and by learning patterns of ‚Äúluck‚Äù. Go to 2 contexts and intuition breaks, coupled 2-context good luck becomes unlikely, ‚Äúnormal accident‚Äù bad luck becomes likely

This is almost the definition of least-effort slacking. The one mitigating factor is that sometimes a context boundary that is taken seriously by others is not actually real so you can exploit a broader single context and seem like a holistic mind-like-water systems thinker.

Example: sociology and management theory are pretty much the same. You need no context switching between them really, just some jargon mapping. Intuition and insight-luck patterns work in nearly seamless ways across them. Ignore the boundary and you‚Äôll look like a genius.

Sometimes you get really meta-lucky and see a really ‚Äúlong‚Äù single-context pathway cutting across multiple specialized stack levels/lifecycle stages. Like a wormhole through learning space. Any move you make in this wormhole context looks like magic to disciplined learners.

I *think* this is what looks like ‚Äústrategic insight‚Äù (coup d‚Äôoeil) from the outside. It‚Äôs really a cheap exploit in the landscape of other people‚Äôs socially embodied institutional ways of knowing, due to improbable concurrences of insubstantial context boundaries. End </sidebar>

Third, it doesn‚Äôt work on things that take more time than social-cache-refresh time constants. For example, ‚Äúblockchain‚Äù was in hive mind for a year, so I was having interesting thoughts about it. But serious work on blockchain takes 3+ yrs. So I‚Äôm recession-weak on the subject.

If I had to name this thinking/pseudo-learning style given its tricks, strengths, and weaknesses, it would probably be ‚Äúparasitic‚Äù. Low-energy, low-effort, derivative survivalism. Like the grasshopper in ant and grasshopper story. 

Occasionally predatory rather than parasitic.

If you find this inspirational/aspirational at some level, curb your enthusiasm. It‚Äôs more curse than blessing. There‚Äôs something very unsatisfying about this, which is why every year or two I take a run at a ‚Äúdeeper‚Äù project that would come easier to disciplined learners.

Hasn‚Äôt worked yet, but I‚Äôm optimistic I‚Äôll eventually do at least one 2+ layer deep thing in my life that‚Äôs more than right-brained arbitrage/surfing or wormhole trickery of environmental learning.

---

## 30. The Cosmic Mirror Test

*March 7, 2019*

I‚Äôm in the non-apocalyptic camp of climate change believers. I don‚Äôt believe even the worst case will make the world uninhabitable. Let‚Äôs say that‚Äôs a 5% likelihood scenario of maybe 90% species loss and even 90% human population decline. But what do those numbers *mean*?

It means: between that extreme and say a middling collapse scenario, a range covering ~50% of outcomes, though the living Earth doesn‚Äôt end, the ‚Äúworld‚Äù as a shared human sense of place does. This would be a psyche trauma we may have in our future. One you could call soul-death.

Humans are the only species that seems to operate by an incoherent but poetic sense of inclusive fitness that includes all life. Call it the Gaia instinct. It is a weird instinct that makes us identify with all life, and extend our identity onto it via anthropomorphic projection.

When we look up at the stars a key thing we see reflected back is our sense of being part of the only known example of ‚Äúlife‚Äù. This is why we obsess over aliens and the Fermi paradox. Even false alarms of bacteria-level life get us excited. Oumuamua got us properly worked up.

That‚Äôs the Gaia instinct. The capacity to feel lonely when looking up at the stars. It‚Äôs a fairly new feeling. It requires a mix of: big telescopes, globalization, discovery of DNA as shared, non-divine basis for life, and a pale-blue-dot/one-earth outside-in view of ourselves.

I bet if we could know for certain there was no life out there, and no hope of interstellar travel, we‚Äôd lose 90% of our interest in space/astronomy. I‚Äôd still be personally interested, because I like stars, black holes and the idea of empty planets. But most would stop caring.

The cosmos is something like a figurative mirror in a cosmic mirror test. You pass the regular mirror test if you can recognize yourself in a mirror (as other apes, and even crows do). You pass the cosmic mirror test if you feel lonely/yearning when you look up at the sky.

Not all humans pass the cosmic mirror test or possess the Gaia instinct. Hardcore libertarians certainly don‚Äôt. Many traditionally religious types don‚Äôt. I suspect many ‚Äúrationalists‚Äù who fetishize ‚Äúoptimization‚Äù don‚Äôt.  That‚Äôs okay. You‚Äôre all just a bit less evolved than me üòá

I think the common factor there is that because they believe in some non-corporeal god (efficient markets, traditional gods, post-singularity-AI and/or simulators) the spiritual valence of the material cosmos is... attenuated shall we say? Head-in-some-noosphere syndrome.

Passing the cosmic mirror test means at some level, you‚Äôre a sort of hyper-atheist. What we see is all there is. Everything else is comforting fiction. You must find both material sustenance and spiritual succor in these living/non-living atoms around us. There‚Äôs nothing else.

Ironically, we hyper-atheists are most vulnerable to soul death because we keep our souls in atoms around us. Those who believe in any religion keep souls in eternalist, aionic, safe spaces. There‚Äôs a nice Dr. House rant about why atheism makes you value life more, not less.

The universe is not exactly a mirror-of-living-earth, and potential alien life wouldn‚Äôt be a ‚Äúreflection‚Äù but there would be sense of mutual recognition if we did find *any* life. Even if it was alien/predator/andromeda-strain style life that ‚Äúrecognizes‚Äù us by trying to kill us.

Back on earth, we‚Äôre not the only creatures with a sense of outer space (turtles and spiders orient towards the moon/stars for example) but we‚Äôre the only ones who experience the Gaia instinct and pass the cosmic mirror test. It‚Äôs not just a firmament with twinkling lights to us.

The earthbound side of the Gaia instinct is caring about an idea like ‚Äú90% species extinction‚Äù. No other species is capable of caring about anything more than its immediate kin, predators, and prey. Local eco-web consciousness only. The Gaia instinct is for tech-modern humans.

As individuals we can feel an individual version of mutual recognition with almost any creature that we can respond to and that responds to us. Cats and dogs of course, but even trees and slugs. Even if that sense of mutuality is an ‚Äúeww‚Äù or pang at cutting down an ancient tree.

THIS is what at risk. Life may go on even in the worse 50% of climate change outcomes, but the Gaia instinct might die. The world will end in the sense of an idea of ourselves reflected back when we look up. Even if we retain a gritty, anthropcene kind of cyber-paleo modernity.

What might end is the capacity to feel the kind of incredibly poignant loneliness that took Hubble, Pioneer 11, shipping containers, and a double helix to deliver to us. It might be the most precious emotion we‚Äôve constructed for our minds to experience. Better than religion.

Our ability to feel this feeling might be perhaps the peak experience of being human if the worse climate futures play out. We might live on, but on a dispiriting subhuman journey. Or we beat the crisis and go on to experience way more on our many frontiers of the spirit.

You may not share this sensibility. But ask yourself: do you possibly not feel this because you‚Äôve short-circuited your capacity to feel it by putting your ‚Äúsoul‚Äù, for lack of a better word, in an illusory place where it cannot die, but doesn‚Äôt truly live either?

This is ultimately what many of us are thinking/feeling when we talk about climate. We‚Äôre not secretly trying to shove Big Government down the world‚Äôs throat. We‚Äôre trying to prevent the soul-death of the world as we know it. Harsh as 90% collapse might be, soul death is worse.

---

## 31. Seen-It-All Syndrome

*March 21, 2019*

If you're reasonably open to experience, intelligent, and good at pattern matching, you'll arrive at a "seen it all" plateau by about age 35-50. It won't be true, but it will feel like it. Genuine, category/pattern busting surprise is harder to find past a point in our universe

People think this is not true because they conflate surprisal with unpredictability. They're not the same. I can't predict a sequence of coin tosses, but almost no sequence of heads/tails would surprise me.  It would take something like tosses producing pi in binary to do that

When you're a baby, surprise is a continuous state. When you're young, it comes overwhelmingly torrentially and you have to affect unflappability to seem cool. But by the time you're about 35, if you like surprise, a certain desperation to seek it out will creep into your life

Surprisal is a cognitive addiction of course, and a good one. But the hits get harder to produce. By 40, fracking surprise out of the universe turns into an advanced cognitive skill.

A naive response is "have you read all the books in the library yet?" or "have you taught yourself advanced quantum mechanics yet?" Former is plain silly. It becomes obvious fairly quickly in a reading life that humans have written 100x more books than they have things to say

The second response is trickier. Of course not all of us are genius enough to grok and appreciate surprisal hidden in depths of the advanced math of quantum mechanics and stuff. But here's the thing: demystifying a subject to drain it of surprise is FAR easier than working in it

Good pop science/math that is decently challenging can demystify a subject for you without giving you the mastery. And a taste of mastery is enough to tell you that there isn't as much surprise there as you might think.

The illusion of having "seen it all" is like the illusion of having found a "formula" for prime numbers that works up to some point. Of course the number of primes is infinite, but you can convince yourself you've seen them all if the next one is too far away for you to count to

Half of all meditation techniques are about regaining the easy-to-surprise beginner mind so ordinary magic of life can surprise in delight you again. 

The other half of meditation techniques are to console yourself because the first half doesn't work as well as advertised üòÜ

But "beginner mind" idea is right in essence. Except you have to generate the surprise within yourself. Thanks to our enormous capacities for denial etc. some of the deepest reserves for mystery and surprise are within you. You just have to be willing to look foolish to tap them

People dimly recognize this and try to pick up new skills and brave early-learning-curve awkwardness as a way to inject freshness into life again. That's not quite right. If you're an advanced pianist, fumbling at tennis won't really help rediscover the surprisability of age 9.

What WILL help is to blow up things where you think you already know it all and find ways to go all fumbling and awkward again. So our notional pianist has to find a way to be a fumbling beginner *at the piano* again.

Self-disruption basically. Trying to inject novelty into your life by learning unrelated new things is like trying to do 3 undergraduate degrees instead of 1 PhD. A series of degrees is a scripted series of self-disruptions. MS mind disrupts BS mind. PhD mind disrupts MS mind.

Doesn't work very well, but the more informal, less scripted version of developing a sense for when you've plateaued in some activity and blowing it up at the right time, to make it new again, but WITHOUT losing the experience earned... that's the real skill of surprise-seeking

Thank you for reading my long-winded justification for my writing mostly sucking this last year üòÜ

Addendum: there is a big element of surrender in accessing surprisal latent in the universe, and it becomes harder to surrender with age because we become addicted to agency. Even when risks are low, we resist. Kids surprise more easily because they surrender more easily.

---

## 32. Turing-Complete Identities

*March 31, 2019*

History is all the identities we‚Äôve inhabited so far

Kinda makes sense that the end of history would be marked by terminal identitarianism. Consequence, not cause. If nobody can find a way to continue everybody‚Äôs identity evolution, history ends.

Identitarian consensus: when everybody agrees what boxes everybody is in. It‚Äôs a much deeper state of stable equilibrium than everybody simply having a fixed identity. The way common knowledge is a deeper equilibrium than mere belief or even mutual belief.

There was a funny Volkswagen ad where an Indian guy responds to some question about yoga with ‚Äújust because I drive a Volkswagen you think I‚Äôm into yoga?‚Äù

It‚Äôs funny because it simultaneously acknowledges and subverts an identitarian consensus

Also Seinfeld anti-dentite joke

An identitarian consensus is also a set of roles and permissions within a narrative. Stereotyping is just the shallowest layer. History ends at an identitarian consensus not because the narrative ends but because it becomes 100% tropey

The instinct behind simple role-swaps (eg female or black superheroes) as a way to break out of an identitarian consensus equilibrium is solid but... naive. Like transposing a tune to a new key rather than composing a new one. Doesn‚Äôt restart history, just phase-shifts it.

An example of a history-restart type shift is from Campbellian Monomyth hero to LeGuinesque Carrier Bag unheroine. Doctor Who pulled that off, though it has other weaknesses.

Real history edition: when women stop leading like men. Good or bad, you can‚Äôt ignore the fact that it‚Äôs equilibrium-breaking history restart/reboot. This ain‚Äôt Margaret Thatcher or Indira Gandhi style https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/30/opinion/women-leadership-jacinda-ardern.html

The link between end of history and identitarian consensus also explains why ‚Äúdiversity‚Äù as a simplistic alternative to a straight-white-male-centric equilibrium doesn‚Äôt work for anything except post-apocalyptic survivalist stories. That‚Äôs just the aftermath of the end of history

To extend the music metaphor, this is not a transposition, it‚Äôs a polyphony degenerating into a cacophony. Random noise around an EoH equilibrium.

Experimenting with fiction has shown me just how terrible social identities are for writing believable, growing characters. It‚Äôs almost like trying to make an address behave like a house. A category error. An address can let you guess a lot about a house but isn‚Äôt itself a house.

Otoh, you can‚Äôt just make up a character from, say, a set of archetypal inner paradoxes. The context matters in a way that becomes immediately obvious when you try to name a character. A name instantly induces a world.

The thing about history-reboot level narratives is that any one local binding, like the name of a key character, immediately binds the rest of the narrative as well. Choosing any one thing is like choosing everything. And now the whole story is a clockwork deterministic universe.

The best you can do is ‚Äúglitch‚Äù the global binding a bit by simultaneously acknowledging/subverting a piece of it, like my Volkswagen-yoga example. This is not an archetypal paradox driving a character OR a world paradox driving a history. It‚Äôs the nexus *between* the two.

This creates *just* enough room, like a 99.9% global binding instead of 100%, for history to get restarted. Tiny new root sneaking through the cracks of a tessellation defining a world.

Note btw that most science fiction is only cosmetically a building of alternative worlds. Much of the average stuff is simple relabeling. The better ones just acknowledge it openly.

An example of doing more is Dark Materials, where cosmetic similarities suggest a glitchy parallel universe that‚Äôs not quite like ours. Deepness in the Sky also pulls that off by constructing an uncanny valley of spider-beings whose story is told via overwrought human mapping.

I‚Äôve been trying to systematize these intuitions by playing with situated archetypes that work across a whole class of worlds rather than inducing a specific one. Then you suggest the whole universe via ‚Äúbeat‚Äù frequencies that emerge in juxtaposition with a familiar universe

Getting back to history, a narrative is only a history if it‚Äôs not in an end-of-history identitarian consensus equilibrium. Good fiction has the feel of history.

It‚Äôs not enough that the world changes (plot) or characters grow individually or in mutuality. The world and characters must change together in, for want of a better term, Turing complete ways. Even a strange attractor or brownian motion won‚Äôt do.

It‚Äôs the entanglement that evolves irreversibly. And the characters don‚Äôt have to be ‚Äúrich‚Äù in a literary sense for this. In fact that‚Äôs often a liability. Even 2d caricatures that are terrible by rules of ‚Äúgood‚Äù character dev can drive historic narrative if entangled right

This stuff is very hard. That‚Äôs why only a few cases have been solved analytically. For example evil twins from evil parallel universes who differ in social identity only by a goatee (van dyke actually...) is a surprisingly sophisticated device if you dig a bit into it.

‚ÄúGood‚Äù and ‚Äúevil‚Äù are shorthand codes/world-hashes for 2 different narrative equilibria, with a leak in either direction capable of restarting history. Good/evil is a property of the *entanglement* between the characters and home universes.

Importantly, social identity is *only* an address. That is why a trivial marker (facial hair) works to distinguish the two universes. It happens to be gendered but that‚Äôs unimportant. It could be a nongendered trait like long hair.

Interestingly, Marxist thought gets this whole idea in a degenerate way: ‚Äúnone of us is free until all of us are free‚Äù or ‚Äúthe oppressor requires liberation as much as the oppressed.‚Äù That‚Äôs a good special case of entangled history.

Where it fails is treating aspects of the context, like class, as immutable. A workers paradise isn‚Äôt classless. It‚Äôs a degenerate one-class, end-of-history society. To transcend class-structure, you need something with equal expressive power that preserves Turing-completeness.

---

## 33. Asking Questions

*April 30, 2019*

99% of the questions people ask in their 20s and early 30s are roughly the same seemingly ‚Äúimportant‚Äù ones everybody has always asked at those ages. And 99% come up with roughly the same answers ranging from pretty dumb to reasonably smart regardless of effort.

The 1% different answers people come up with might make them somewhat more famous/rich, but are rarely different enough to change much beyond their own lives. The age-old questions are age old because the answers are in our collective diminishing marginal returns zone.

They are important, like air or water, but they aren‚Äôt wellsprings of meaning. How to make money, how to get laid, how politics works, who is good/bad, how to choose friends. You‚Äôll spend 99% of your time on this stuff getting to useful and necessary but uninteresting places.

But if you trace back the most interesting, meaningful things people have done by 40s, you‚Äôll usually find them asking a new *question* in 20s/early 30s nobody thought was worth asking. The questions are rarely deep/subtle. Many people consider them, but few do so seriously.

Even the most unimportant question can create a lot of meaning if it‚Äôs a new question and you‚Äôre one of few asking it at right age. This 1% of questions you ask should occupy 20% of your attention. The other 99% important-and-age-old questions deserve only 80% of  attention, why?

It‚Äôs because the 99% questions have been so milked to death by people asking them over 6000 years of recorded human history and writing down the answers, you can really triage the hell out of them. Most answers that have survived are ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù. Pick a lazy one and move on.

If you were a 34-year-old mediocre-intelligent guy and had to choose between spending 10 hours asking one of these questions in say 2009...

1. Is conservatism better/worse than liberalism?

2. Why is ‚ÄúThe Office‚Äù so funny

3. How to fix economy?

Which one would you have chosen?

Like everybody else, I was asking 1 and 3, and got nowhere interesting. I didn‚Äôt do much worse or better than others on those (important) Qs.

What I did right was get bored enough with 1 and 3 to accept lazy answers and move on. Everything interesting in my life came out of Q2.

I‚Äôm sure others in their 40s have similar examples. My point is 25-40 is your most valuable, imaginative, intelligent and bold time of life, where your powers are at their peak, your life constraints are at their weakest, and your energy at its most boundless.

Don‚Äôt waste this period asking age-old questions everybody has been spending 99% of their youth asking through all history. Triage them, get to good enough, and find *new* questions that *few* people are asking. The more average you are, the more crucial this hack.

Exceptional geniuses might find unexpectedly high chunks of new marginal value in age-old actively-worked questions (age-old but abandoned/rarely asked questions are different, almost as good as new, but rarely as easy). You, statistically likely to be a mediocrity like me, won‚Äôt

And never let seeming triviality or unimportance stop you from investing demented amounts of energy into the answers. Even if everybody thinks you‚Äôre crazy. Novelty never wears its significance and hidden value on the cover.

---

## 34. Wealth/Success Monoculture in the US

*August 4, 2019*

Been reflecting on wealth and success (in conventional sense, which may involve some combination of wealth, fame, accomplishment, historic impact,  etc) lately.

Both are things I am not personally very motivated by. But they are not things I have a problem with either.

The US is a society that fetishizes wealth and success. It takes its societal organization cues almost entirely from the dynamics of wealth and success. Much can be explained by people either idolizing or demonizing wealth and success.

There‚Äôs no such thing as a centrist in the US when it comes to wealth/success. Believing that wealth/success are neither essentially good/evil, or virtuous/sinful, is not an option. You must construct a totalizing view of society as an extension of wealth/success views.

This is something I cannot grok deeply. I can only run American ‚Äúwealth/success calculus‚Äù in emulation mode. I know many wealthy and/or successful people as well as many destitute and/or unsuccessful people. W/S has low correlation with whether I‚Äôll find someone interesting.

To me wealthy or successful people are simply people who set out to solve for wealth or success in some sense, and succeed. Others who try, fail. It is what it is.

Their stories reveal very little about the nature of the human condition beyond the nature of wealth/success.

This is a thought many Americans seem incapable of thinking, but it is possible to live a life based on solving for other things: service, happiness, spirituality, adventure, thrills, family, etc. Most societies in history have had people solving for all of these.

What makes the US unique is the extent to which wealth/success monopolizes life scripts and contaminates even other scripts. You can‚Äôt just set out to be a nurse or a monk, you must set out to be a rich and successful nurse or monk. Even if that‚Äôs an incoherent thing to want.

Wealth/success monoculture has specific effects . On valorization side:

1. Horatio Algerism (assuming the wealth/success = wisdom, integrity, enlightenment

2. Fascination with half-assed Big Man theories

3. Crippling phobia of anything that even has a hint of socialism

On the demonization side:

1. Conspiracist fever dreams about the Bond-villainy of wealthy/successful

2. Socialist leanings oriented to a true north of ressentiment rather than compassion

3. Delusional recoding of mediocre prole lives as ‚Äúwealthy and successful‚Äù

Second-order effects:

1. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a billionaire... yet‚Äù life scripts
2. A ‚Äúwaiting to arrive‚Äù life posture
3. Desperate insecurity around differentiation of individual identity
4. Distortion of justice into identity politics
5. Aestheticization over mitigation of poverty/misery

6. Treating of poverty or lack of success as a character flaw rather than just ‚Äúit is what it is‚Äù

7. Systematic downplaying of the role of chance (even by the demonizers who overweight determinate structural oppression by the wealthy/successful in social explanations)

The structural/institutional effects are all over the place. 

Drug war, ridiculous incarceration rates, casting of any social cost problem as a ‚Äúyou‚Äôre trying to shill for/punish wealth/success‚Äù...

Signaling oriented consumerism, premium mediocrity...

The darkest effects are around things the US expends vast amounts of energy and capital in but barely talks about in anything like an appropriate proportion: healthcare, military adventurism, etc.

Why? Because attitudes to wealth/success imply very little of use on these issues

If you try to derive a sound view on healthcare, military adventures, or climate action from whether you love or hate billionaires or movie stars, you will end up with ridiculous cartoon views because these problems are fundamentally not even about wealth/success.

Note that obsessive focus on wealth/success is something of a self-fulfilling prophecy. More individuals will be wealthy and/or successful as a fraction of the population and the society in aggregate will also be more wealthy and successful. But median is not the same as maximum.

You‚Äôll have more billionaires and rockstars per capital and higher GDP and growth perhaps. But you‚Äôll also be more cruel to your poor, sick, dying than societies with less individual/collective wealth/success. You‚Äôll have bigger social costs, snowballing faster.

You will de facto criminalize lack of success or wealth. Your ability to solve for anything else (wisdom, compassion) will atrophy, because those are skills too.

Privilege literally means private law. That will become the only kind of law. Public law will become prison yard law.

Solving for wealth/success will look like breaking out of prison. If you‚Äôre not born to privilege, you‚Äôll be born into increasingly prison-like situations, designed to contain, coerce, punish, tame. What I call breaking smart in more optimistic writing will become breaking out.

All countries have their share of transient problems, acute crises, chronic structural problems, and existential paradoxes. But the US probably has the most severe collective mental health problem among countries I think I grok. And the root cause is a wealth/success monoculture.

All this just makes me sad. 

The hard part is that America is highly attached to its wealth/success orientation as both a great national strength and the root of its exceptionalism narrative. 

It is hard to accept that your greatest strength can also be your greatest weakness.

Arrested development is *always* rooted in a sense of one‚Äôs strength. It is hard to move past this condition because it‚Äôs hard to notice when a strength stops being a strength and turns into a limiting self-perception.

I have no suggestions. America will either grow or die.

Btw, inequality, wealth concentration, cronyism, financialization of everything: all these are not ‚Äúproblems‚Äù. The are natural consequences of W/S values and enjoy basic moral sanction. If wealth+success = good, anything that favors it can at worst be inefficient, not bad.

The ‚Äúproblem‚Äù America has with these things is that they let ‚Äúundeserving‚Äù people get wealthy and successful, and prevent greater peaks being reached by bigger Big Men, not because they make the poor more miserable or prisons more terrible.

America has more compassion for Bezos being harassed by Trump than people scammed by Trump University. More compassion for a well-funded startup being blocked from a market by a protectionist crony sector than people being actively hurt by the social costs of that sector.

---

## 35. Memory Genres

*September 23, 2019*

Here‚Äôs a spectrum of ‚Äúmemory‚Äù genres

1. Autobiography
2. Family history
3. Personal memoir
4. Subcultural history
5. Public life memoir
6. Participant history

Prediction: All of it is in trouble. Our cultural memory processes are breaking.

1. Autobiography is in trouble because it‚Äôs gone quantum. Living and narrating have gotten entangled live for anyone whose life might be of interest to others. You can‚Äôt just live an interesting life and then write it down. There‚Äôs a competing record of how you performed it live.

2. Family history is reality TV (it has been Kardashianized)

This has been kinda dead for a while anyway. Families have been a poor unit of broader cultural memory since hereditary nobility kinda became obsolete as a type of storage.

3. Personal memoir is suffering an odd fate ‚Äî people are no longer sufficiently entangled in each other‚Äôs lives for long enough for that to be an interesting way to capture memories. It‚Äôs better to take a different slice, like the history of a neighborhood.

4. Subcultural history is probably the only gainer here, but average size of meaningful subcultures has been declining. As memory, it‚Äôs like replacing 10 1TB discs with 10k 1GB discs. The memories are being captured in a different frequency range. We‚Äôre high-pass filtering.

5. Public life memoirs are falling prey to fake news, weaponized revelations and whistleblowing, and a Rashomon effect. It‚Äôs unclear if live experiences are being captured in a way that allows for definitive accounts.

6. And finally, regular history is just kinda toast. Long story (ironic huh?)

The future of collective memory is multitemporal. Starting ~2000, increasingly, history will be seen to have a multiple personality disorder. No canonical history plus wistful counterfactuals. Just a superposition of non-consensus histories. Like a diffraction pattern.

This is the rough collective version of this individual-scale argument https://www.ribbonfarm.com/2019/05/30/the-age-of-diffraction/

This idea is probably much clearer in my head than it is to anyone else ü§î

Simplest example I can think of: accounts of Obama administration at all these levels will harmonize (including the hostile ones) in a way the equivalent Trump corpus won‚Äôt. It‚Äôs a fundamentally higher entropy story. Smaller ‚Äòsum > parts‚Äô narrative surplus to form grand narrative

Basically there won‚Äôt be a way to adopt a point of view that could call default or canonical. Only a bunch of alts. There will be nothing it is like to be a ‚Äúspectator from nowhere‚Äù of history. If you try to write for this point of view there will be no readers for it.

All history will be revisionist history basically, with the role of default being taken over by a data ubiquity that tells no story, but undermines all of them.

The log level shall reign supreme

Collective memory is a form of identity creation. A way to create a point of view that can be adopted by others in the future. That‚Äôs how you engineer read/write/append access to it. This is now becoming untenable except as solipsism.

To quote myself: narratives tell archetypes how to evolve, archetypes tell narratives how to curve.

Narratives become indexical to self perpetuate by enabling identities with rewrite permission. 

Soon: all history is revisionist, all integration of memory is appropriation üòÜ

---

## 36. Mock Shocks and Rube Revelations

*October 4, 2019*

Looking for that Hangover 3 scene where they‚Äôre planning the break-in around a model of the target house and  Alan says ‚Äúguys, you know this isn‚Äôt the house we have to break into right? Te real house is much bigger!‚Äù

A lot of supposed radical acts of truth strike me as like that

It‚Äôs the opposite of the mock shock affected by sophisticated cynics at revelations they consider not shocking st all, the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm shocked, SHOCKED‚Äù line that nobody uses these days in non-mocking ways.

Maybe opposite of Mock Shock is Rube Revelation?

When people act like they‚Äôre doing a brave act of radical truth telling, and are sincere about it, but nobody else is enlightened because they weren‚Äôt confused about it in the first place. The rube just projects their childish confusions onto a nonexistent common knowledge gap.

Rube revelation is to genuine heresy as bullshit is to truth. It‚Äôs not deliberate attempt to pass off common knowledge banalities as radical heresy, its an indifference to the distinction

Often cascades of rube revelation are started by something like a marginal common knowledge act. You take something 80% get (and know others get) that is too simple to mention and loudly belabor it at ELI5 level as radical insight till the 20% rubes get it.

This gets the rubes...

a) stoked on a supposed elite conspiracy to hide deep truths (which is really just not belaboring the obvious) 

b) rolling on a rube revelation cascade that‚Äôs 99% banality, 1% accidental nefarious-elite-machinations unmasking

There is something deeply disingenuous about this. Playing mock martyr to raise a mook army of newly enraged rubes reveling in faux-red-pill ‚Äúenlightenment‚Äù.

Among other things this is where conspiracy theory epistemology starts.

The instigator of the Rube Enlightenment gets lionized as a liberating Paladin for the masses, newly armed and empowered with The Truth to act against evil elites. Now that they know the earth is flat and that q anon is The Truth, it‚Äôs all deep state x-files lies.

The massively energized rube detective force is now on the move ripping the mask off the face of naked elite oppression. For every pizzagate that turns out to line up with an Epstein scandal, a million libraries must be burned, a million flat-earth theories enshrined as knowledge

An age-old pattern: wannabe kings allying with peasants to take down the feudal gentry in the middle. It‚Äôs an example of what Jaron Lanier labeled Digital Maoism (in Edge, ironically). Hack the Noble Lies to install the People‚Äôs Truths forged in the fires of righteous rage.

Whether the People‚Äôs Truth finds expression in a new Rule of Woke Law or the Cleansing Commandments of Divine God-Emperor Zorgon the Heretic makes no difference. 

It‚Äôs a Book of Rube Revelations in either case. Fundamentally a stupid person‚Äôs idea of political wisdom.

This isn‚Äôt bothsidesing. It is signalsiding. Bothsidesing is acting like both sides of a false symmetry have equal validity, either because you‚Äôre dumb or because you‚Äôre disingenuous.

‚Äúthe opposite of a great truth is also a great truth‚Äù). You really think we‚Äôre great-truthing?

If both sides are 90% noise, do the math. About 81% of the time both sides are being stupid, 9% of the time one side is right by accident and the other side is bothsidesing out of stupidity or malice.

About, 1% of the time it‚Äôs a great truth in contention. By accident probably.

Signal-siding is basically ignoring the stupid people, and continuing to actually think, even at the risk of perhaps missing the 1% great-truth debates.

Centrism is stupid or disingenuous because it acts like bothsidesing is meaningful 99% of the time instead of 1%.

Noise vs noise does not net to signal via mutual cancelation (heh!), it is noise squared. 

Signal is neither consensus or heresy by cosmic preference. Nor is it common sense or esoterically technical by preference, Signal is indifferent to self-important epistemic posturing.

The truth, such as it is, does not lie on the Rube Revelation spectrum at all. And smart elites who should know better but act like it does, raising mook armies and winking at the snowballing crackpottery and Maoist trials of their rivals among the elites are just seeking power.

If vast armies of enraged rubes rally around you, celebrating how you, the Rare Good Elite are absolutely tearing apart those awful Typical Bad Elites, you‚Äôre probably not catalyzing a Great Consciousness Raising among the masses. You‚Äôre cynically making a play for more power.

Basically, in this environment, anyone who attempts to shape opinions on a large mass-media scale, pwning millions of minds to coerce hundreds of millions of minds into ideological submission, is basically a bad person. It‚Äôs as clear a tell as pouring gasoline into a fire.

When you avoid the temptation to traffic in the Epistemic Status: Rube Revelation idea economy, you will find your audience hitting a low ceiling. Signal-siding in a noisy environment is like trying to have a conversation in a loud party with blaring music and drunken brawls.

Only the 5 people next to you and straining to understand you above the noise are signalsiding whatever you are saying. 

If the whole room hears you above the noise, music, and brawling, almost certainly you yelled something loud, stupid, and dangerous. Like ‚ÄúFire!‚Äù

---

## 37. On Independent Research

*November 16, 2019*

I was briefly calling myself an independent researcher: somebody who self-funds spec R&D on their own ideas. In theory it‚Äôs something like indie-research : academic research :: blogging/self-publishing : traditional publishing.

But the idea doesn‚Äôt really work.

Unlike the market for general interest writing, the market for R&D is almost entirely institutional, and they don‚Äôt really ‚Äúbuy‚Äù indie R&D. It‚Äôs 99.9% crackpot inventors, 0.1% black swan stuff.

Most ‚Äúresearch‚Äù indie consultants sell institutions is in the market-research class, not academic research

If I spent 6 months working on a new robot navigation algorithm or a study of government failure risk in Latin America or a deep study of some artist, nobody would buy it at a price that would pat for what it cost to do even in pure living costs terms.

You can at best target a research problem on a marketplace where someone has already declared a bounty, like say innocentive, nine sigma, etc (in which case they‚Äôre few and narrow). But that‚Äôs hardly independent. If you want to define and work on a problem you choose, it‚Äôs your $

Research = 

a) long time between having an idea and having something to show for it that even the most sympathetic fellow crackpot would appreciate (not even pat for, just get)

b) a >10:1 ratio of background invisible thinking in notes, dead-ends, eliminating options etc

With a blogpost, it‚Äôs like a week of effort at most from idea to mvp, and at most a 3:1 ratio of invisible to visible. That‚Äôs sustainable as a hobby/side thing. 

To do research-grade thinking you basically have to be independently wealthy and accept 90% deadweight losses

John Carmack announcing he was quitting oculus to do indie research on AGI finally made the stark equation clear. You need Carmack-level starting points (indie wealth, established R&D celebrity record) to go indie. That‚Äôs basically modern equivalent of old nobility.

That‚Äôs the real deal. Anyone below that threshold calling themselves an independent researcher is either talking about something like market research or trend research (which is really environmental intelligence work not R&D in the sense that interests me), deluded, or lying.

tldr: Get tenure, or get rich. Software has not eaten R&D, and won‚Äôt eat it anytime soon. Possible outliers like Satoshi (who may have been in an R&D institution or indie-wealthy in 2009 for all we know) notwithstanding.

Best-case outcome if neither applies: your idea has commercial potential and you can get a startup out of it. Which means the vast majority of ideas, both STEM and humanities, are out. Even I‚Äôm not optimist enough to think your R&D on 16rh century French poets can be a unicorn.

The reason software doesn‚Äôt eat R&D even though people think it should is that tools or open access to published lit/libraries, or free peer-reviewed publishing/presentation forums (if you want that) are only a tiny fraction of the cost for most ideas. The main host is time.

Even if the most expensive research tools like LHC or Hubble got as cheap as Arduinos, it wouldn‚Äôt help. That‚Äôs not the cost bottleneck. The bottleneck is researcher time. Even crappiest, cheapest conference paper I ever wrote took at least 6 months (~7k grad student salary then)

This isn‚Äôt cheap talk btw. I dropped 2k on a personal Matlab license after I went indie and kept it current for years, and went through dozens of false starts working on various ideas. Couldn‚Äôt find the time to develop any of them to even bad-conference-paper level.

Note: peer-reviewed publishing or patents just as depth cal9bration. I wouldn‚Äôt necessarily publish in such forms since I don‚Äôt think those institutional processes have ever added much to my work. Nor into them tbf, in the peer reviewing I‚Äôve done. But I‚Äôd aim for that depth.

Note #2: I enjoy proper research, but wasn‚Äôt a great talent even at my peak and am now likely at 60%. So in a way this is an okay market outcome. If I were wealthy I might do self-indulgent mediocre research for the rest of my life, but no reason you should pay for it.

Note #3

Learning projects to prepare to go deep on a subject are not research even if it feels like it

Reading published literature and blogging a few derivative observations is not research

Critiquing/finding flaws in published papers is indie peer-review, not research

I find that autodidacts who haven‚Äôt experienced institutional R&D environments have a self-congratulatory low threshold for what they count as research. It‚Äôs a bit like vanity publishing or fan fiction. This mismatch doesn‚Äôt exist as much in indie art, consulting, game dev etc

I‚Äôm on a year-long fellowship right now, and this is partly what has made me admit the conceit in the ‚Äúindie researcher‚Äù self-label. I‚Äôm doing this sort of thinking for the first time since ~2006 or so (the year I last submitted a paper to a peer-reviewed journal). https://twitter.com/kevinmarks/status/1195806039708520448

It‚Äôs also reminding me how much I enjoy doing the real thing. It‚Äôs like a year long vacation back to my own past.

Ironically, most modern tenured faculty don‚Äôt get to do much R&D either, at least in STEM. They‚Äôre too busy fund-raising. They‚Äôre more like angel investors and board advisors to grad students and postdocs. Humanities and social sciences may perhaps be better, I don‚Äôt know.

If you‚Äôre thinking kickstarter-like funding mechanisms, forget it. You‚Äôll be asking for 10x as much money as typical artistic or startuppy projects, have no natural rewards to hand out, and a far lower likelihood of success.

A good public example: Breaking Smart S2 was a medium-depth research project I thought I could sustain on my own (a16z supported S1). I gave up looking for funding after a couple of half-hearted pitches to orgs I thought might be a fit for the topic.

The topic I wanted to research, and got about 1/3 the way through, was institution building in the Great Weirding. It‚Äôs the sort of thing that‚Äôs not a natural fit for any corporate funding source.

Current plan is to package and flush out what I have so far as a sort of ‚ÄúChristmas Special‚Äù about 1/5 the scope/ambition of S1.

A more basic problem with kickstarter type ideas is that anyone good at creating the buzz and hype for that is almost by definition going to be bad at R&D and vice versa. Content mismatch aside.

Writing grant proposals to satisfy a few bureaucrats is already enough of a mismatch to research personalities. Crowd-pleasing requires 10x that painful mismatch.

List of actually credible indie researchers

1. Stephen Wolfram (math/complexity/computation)
2. Jeff Hawkins (neuroscience)
3. John Carnack (AGI)

Notice something, besides the fact they‚Äôre smart and have the right subject-matter prep?

They got rich first üôÇ

Don‚Äôt mean to be a downer. There‚Äôs possibly imaginative models that could work in indie mode that I simply haven‚Äôt thought of.

Many things get called ‚Äúresearch‚Äù and a lot of ego-sensitivity gets attached to it. I think of it mainly in terms of (high risk of no valuable output)*(high ratio of invisible to visible output)*(high time demands). Let me try to pseudo-quantify this and take the ego element out:

1. Intelligence briefs
2. Gartneresque research
3. Investigative journalism
3. Market research
4. Broad societal trend research
5. Data-heavy trend research, pure math
6. Tech futures, humanities
7.  S/W tech, social science
8. Generic STEM
9. Big science
10. Paradigm shifts

This scale isn‚Äôt commentary on the intelligence, creativity, or imagination of the people who do such work. Higher on the scale is simply riskier, more time-consuming, and requires more backend work, even holding the human factor constant

One thing I probably could do is raise funding for a small research institution/lab working on problems in the 6-8 range. Maybe 4-5 staff. The thing is I don‚Äôt want to run a research org, which is an entirely different interest/ambition than doing research. It takes a COO type.

Strange-looping in a secondary meta thread I did later. https://twitter.com/vgr/status/1195937380210921472

---

## 38. On Independent Research II

*November 17, 2019*

Thinking about my thread this morning on why independent research is hard, and what it would take to make it possible, and whether it‚Äôs within the reach of private investors who ALL complain endlessly about how they have far too much capital and don‚Äôt know where to put it. https://twitter.com/vgr/status/1195789557465153536

On one extreme you can think UBI, which is roughly ~ early grad student level $. 

On the other extreme, you could think of early career faculty grants.

An NSF CAREER grant is 100k/year for 5 yrs, and in 2018, about 150 million was disbursed or about 300.

A subset of ~20 get PECASE awards which push up the 100k to 500k/yr, sp that‚Äôs another 40 million. This 190 million basically supports 300 new faculty every year which I think is approximately ALL new faculty in say the top 25-30 universities.

At grad student stipend level, you‚Äôre talking about a quarter that. 25k/year. So you could support about 1200 grad student level researchers for the same amount. So $19- million gets you somewhere between 300 to 1200 bets on independent researchers. Now who can afford that?

Let‚Äôs look at Silicon Valley.  Last I checked, Series A, B, C, and D rounds are ~10 million, 20mm, 50mm, 100mm. Might be off by a bit.

So... doubling research capacity of entire university system = 20 As, 10 Bs, 4 Cs, or 2 Ds.

Entirely within the capacity of SV capital market

I‚Äôm making this arithmetic comparison because SV investors sometimes act like basic research is entirely out of their reach and all they can do is draft off of output of big government R&D programs running over decades. This is just not true anymore.

SV people tend to be free market ideologues, yet their free market idealism mysteriously vanishes when talking about this stuff. SoftBank alone could fund something like this probably.

And indie research would dispense with indirect cost support (~50% overhead charge that research universities typically charge agencies to pay for brick-and-mortar infrastructure, a big innovation in its time, due to Vannevar Bush).

Basically there‚Äôs a bullshit R&D funnel argument that people trot out to explain slowing of new business formation and general innovation stagnation/falling business dynamism (similar to the one around diversity in tech hiring).

The research university model worked well for about 60 years after WW2. It supplied both the talent and the IP feedstock (not just STEM, humanities/liberal arts as well) to drive American business growth an leadership. Z

Basically free in-kind money for the innovation economy.

Now that model is struggling, I have to wonder why huge capital stocks created from that legacy investment aren‚Äôt being plowed back into the head of the funnel. 

Possibly SV has gotten used to easy private wealth building off of publicly funded feedstock.

I think the R&D loop can be closed with tech wealth and investment capital. Universities can be unbundled. There‚Äôs no good reason to keep teaching, research, and service in the same costly brick and mortar bundle anymore.

I bet every top 5 VC,  PE, and Big Tech firm could each sustain 20% NSF CAREER type indie research network, 3x-ing total R&D bandwidth of the US. 

With expectations of open source/license output. Restock the commons without need for big 60s/70s style government programs.

I‚Äôd revamp publishing, peer review models, etc, as well, since the model that exists is failing even for university research (hence reproducibility crisis, impact factor gaming, purely cronyism predatory journal empires etc) but that‚Äôs a secondary mechanism design problem.

Income-share education models already exist and offer a competitive alternative to the teaching function of universities and get out of the unsustainable student debt balloon. 

R&D can be unbundled too.

What‚Äôs the alternative? The innovation economy finally kills the dying golden goose for the last few golden eggs, and enters a late stage fraud economy competing with NIMBY grifters in decaying urban cores. Stockbuybackitis infects SV too. The music stops.
